DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms Primary Anatomic Site SNOMED-CT Anatomic Site Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The response indicating the name of the primary anatomic site where the disease is located that has not previously been specified.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms Primary Anatomic Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_Published by the College of American Pathologists, the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms is a combination of content of SNOMED Reference Terminology and READ codes._Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value._Named locations of or within the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Concepts.longName: Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms
Concepts.definition: Published by the College of American Pathologists, the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms is a combination of content of SNOMED Reference Terminology and READ codes.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
Named locations of or within the body.
